canonical_explanation.text: A current-carrying conductor produces a magnetic field around it. The direction of the magnetic field due to a straight conductor is given by the right-hand thumb rule. A solenoid carrying current behaves like a bar magnet. An electromagnet is a temporary magnet made by winding a coil around a soft iron core. A current-carrying conductor placed in a magnetic field experiences a force, the direction of which is given by Fleming's left-hand rule — this is the principle behind an electric motor. When a conductor moves in a magnetic field (or a magnetic field changes near a conductor), an electric current is induced — this is electromagnetic induction, discovered by Faraday. The direction of induced current is given by Fleming's right-hand rule. Electric generators work on electromagnetic induction. Domestic circuits use live (red/brown), neutral (black/blue), and earth (green) wires, with safety devices like fuses and MCBs.
rules: Right-hand thumb rule gives the direction of magnetic field around a straight current-carrying conductor.
A solenoid carrying current produces a magnetic field similar to a bar magnet.
Fleming's left-hand rule gives the direction of force on a current-carrying conductor in a magnetic field.
Electric motor converts electrical energy to mechanical energy using Fleming's left-hand rule.
Electromagnetic induction: changing magnetic field induces current (Faraday's discovery).
Fleming's right-hand rule gives the direction of induced current.
Electric generator converts mechanical energy to electrical energy using electromagnetic induction.
Domestic circuits use live, neutral, and earth wires with fuse/MCB for safety.

questions.question_text: Magnetic field lines around a bar magnet:

options.text: Start from south pole and end at north pole
Start from north pole and end at south pole
Do not exist outside the magnet

questions.explanation_correct: Magnetic field lines outside the magnet emerge from the north pole and enter the south pole. Inside the magnet, they run from south to north, forming continuous closed loops. This direction is by convention.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Magnetic field lines go from north pole to south pole outside the magnet, not from south to north. They form continuous closed curves and are not always straight — they are curved around the magnet.

questions.question_text: The region around a magnet where its magnetic effect can be experienced is called the:
questions.explanation_correct: The region surrounding a magnet in which the force of the magnet can be detected is called the magnetic field. It is represented by magnetic field lines and its strength decreases with distance from the magnet.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The magnetic pole is the end of a magnet. The magnetic axis is the line joining the poles. The magnetic moment is a measure of the magnet's strength. The region around a magnet where its effect is felt is called the magnetic field.

questions.question_text: Two magnetic field lines:
questions.explanation_correct: Two magnetic field lines never intersect each other. If they did, it would mean that at the point of intersection, the compass needle would point in two different directions simultaneously, which is impossible. The magnetic field has a unique direction at every point.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Magnetic field lines can never intersect because at any given point, the magnetic field has only one direction. If two lines crossed, there would be two directions at the same point, which is physically impossible.

questions.question_text: Where is the magnetic field strongest around a bar magnet?

options.text: At the centre of the magnet

questions.explanation_correct: The magnetic field is strongest near the poles of a bar magnet, where the field lines are closest together (most dense). The closeness of field lines indicates the strength of the field — the denser the lines, the stronger the field.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The magnetic field is not uniform or strongest at the centre. It is strongest near the poles where the field lines are most crowded. The field weakens as you move away from the magnet.

questions.question_text: The rule used to determine the direction of magnetic field around a straight current-carrying conductor is:
questions.explanation_correct: The right-hand thumb rule (also called Maxwell's corkscrew rule) is used to find the direction of the magnetic field around a straight current-carrying conductor. If the thumb points in the direction of current, the curled fingers show the direction of the magnetic field.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Fleming's left-hand rule is for finding force on a conductor in a magnetic field. Fleming's right-hand rule is for electromagnetic induction. The right-hand thumb rule is specifically for finding the direction of the magnetic field around a current-carrying conductor.

questions.question_text: The magnetic field lines around a straight current-carrying conductor are:
questions.explanation_correct: The magnetic field lines around a straight current-carrying conductor are concentric circles centered on the wire. The plane of these circles is perpendicular to the conductor, and their direction is given by the right-hand thumb rule.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The field lines around a straight conductor are not straight, elliptical, or spiral. They form concentric circles in a plane perpendicular to the wire, centered on the conductor.

questions.question_text: A solenoid carrying current behaves like a:
questions.explanation_correct: A current-carrying solenoid (a coil of many circular turns of wire) produces a magnetic field pattern that is similar to that of a bar magnet. One end acts as the north pole and the other as the south pole, with a uniform field inside the solenoid.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A solenoid carrying current produces a magnetic field similar to a bar magnet, not a capacitor, resistor, or battery. It has a north and south pole at its two ends and produces a strong, nearly uniform magnetic field inside.

questions.question_text: The magnetic field inside a solenoid is:
questions.explanation_correct: The magnetic field inside a solenoid is uniform and strong. The field lines inside the solenoid are parallel, equidistant, and directed from the south pole end to the north pole end (inside). This uniform field is one of the important properties of a solenoid.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The field inside a solenoid is neither zero nor non-uniform. It is strong and uniform (parallel field lines). The uniform nature of the internal field makes solenoids useful in many applications.

questions.question_text: An electromagnet is made by wrapping a coil around a core of:
questions.explanation_correct: An electromagnet is made by winding a coil around a core of soft iron. Soft iron is used because it is easily magnetised and demagnetised. When the current flows, the soft iron core becomes a strong magnet, and when the current stops, it loses its magnetism.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Soft iron is preferred over steel because it can be easily magnetised and demagnetised. Steel retains magnetism (used for permanent magnets). Copper is non-magnetic. Wood is a poor choice as it does not enhance the magnetic field.

questions.question_text: The rule used to find the direction of force on a current-carrying conductor placed in a magnetic field is:
questions.explanation_correct: Fleming's left-hand rule is used to determine the direction of the force on a current-carrying conductor placed in a magnetic field. The forefinger represents the magnetic field (B), the middle finger represents the current (I), and the thumb gives the direction of the force (F).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Fleming's left-hand rule (not right-hand rule or right-hand thumb rule) gives the force direction. In this rule: forefinger = field, middle finger = current, thumb = force direction (motion).

questions.question_text: An electric motor converts:
questions.explanation_correct: An electric motor converts electrical energy into mechanical energy (rotational motion). It works on the principle that a current-carrying conductor placed in a magnetic field experiences a force (Fleming's left-hand rule).
questions.explanation_incorrect: An electric motor converts electrical energy to mechanical energy, not the other way around. A generator converts mechanical to electrical energy. A battery converts chemical to electrical energy.

questions.question_text: In a DC electric motor, the split ring acts as a:
questions.explanation_correct: In a DC motor, the split ring acts as a commutator. Its function is to reverse the direction of current in the coil every half rotation so that the coil continues to rotate in the same direction. Without the commutator, the coil would oscillate back and forth instead of rotating continuously.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The split ring in a DC motor is called a commutator. The armature is the rotating coil. The commutator reverses the current direction every half turn to ensure continuous rotation in one direction.

questions.question_text: The force experienced by a current-carrying conductor in a magnetic field is maximum when the angle between the conductor and the field is:
questions.explanation_correct: The force on a current-carrying conductor in a magnetic field is F = BIl sin θ, where θ is the angle between the conductor and the magnetic field. The force is maximum when θ = 90° (sin 90° = 1) and zero when θ = 0° (conductor parallel to field).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The force is maximum when the conductor is perpendicular (90°) to the magnetic field. At 0° (parallel to the field), the force is zero. The force depends on sin θ, which is maximum at 90°.

questions.question_text: The phenomenon of producing electric current by changing the magnetic field is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Electromagnetic induction is the phenomenon of producing an electric current (or EMF) by changing the magnetic field around a conductor. It was discovered by Michael Faraday and forms the basis of electric generators.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The production of electric current by a changing magnetic field is called electromagnetic induction, not the motor effect (which is force on a current-carrying conductor), electrostatic effect, or heating effect.

questions.question_text: Electromagnetic induction was discovered by:
questions.explanation_correct: Electromagnetic induction was discovered by Michael Faraday in 1831. He showed that a changing magnetic field in the vicinity of a conductor induces an electric current in the conductor. This discovery is the basis for electric generators and transformers.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Newton is known for laws of motion and gravity. Ohm discovered the relationship between voltage and current. Ampere studied magnetic effects of current. Electromagnetic induction was discovered by Michael Faraday.

questions.question_text: The rule used to find the direction of induced current is:
questions.explanation_correct: Fleming's right-hand rule is used to find the direction of the induced current (or induced EMF) in electromagnetic induction. The forefinger represents the magnetic field, the thumb represents the motion of the conductor, and the middle finger gives the direction of the induced current.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Fleming's right-hand rule (not left-hand rule) is used for electromagnetic induction. The left-hand rule is for motor effect (force on conductor). The right-hand rule determines the direction of induced current when a conductor moves in a magnetic field.

questions.question_text: An electric generator converts:
questions.explanation_correct: An electric generator converts mechanical energy into electrical energy. It works on the principle of electromagnetic induction — when a coil is rotated in a magnetic field, the changing magnetic flux induces an electric current in the coil.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A generator converts mechanical energy to electrical energy. A motor does the opposite (electrical to mechanical). A battery converts chemical to electrical energy. The generator uses electromagnetic induction.

questions.question_text: The difference between a DC generator and an AC generator is in the:

options.text: Type of rings — split rings vs slip rings

questions.explanation_correct: The main difference between a DC and AC generator is in the type of rings used. A DC generator uses split rings (commutator) to convert AC to DC output, while an AC generator uses slip rings that allow the current to alternate direction as the coil rotates.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The fundamental difference is in the rings: a DC generator uses split rings (commutator) while an AC generator uses continuous slip rings. Both use similar coils, magnetic fields, and can operate at similar speeds.

questions.question_text: In India, the frequency of alternating current (AC) supply is:
questions.explanation_correct: In India, the frequency of the alternating current supply is 50 Hz. This means the current changes direction 100 times per second (50 complete cycles per second). In the US and some other countries, 60 Hz is used.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The AC supply frequency in India is 50 Hz, not 25, 60, or 100 Hz. At 50 Hz, the current completes 50 full cycles per second, changing direction 100 times per second.

questions.question_text: The colour of the live wire in a domestic circuit (new code) is:
questions.explanation_correct: In the new colour code used in India, the live wire is brown (or red in the old code). The neutral wire is blue (or black in old code), and the earth wire is green (or green with yellow stripes).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The live wire is brown (new code) or red (old code). Green is the earth wire. Black was the old neutral colour. Blue is the neutral wire in the new colour code.

questions.question_text: The function of an earth wire in a domestic circuit is to:

options.text: Provide safety by directing leakage current to the ground

questions.explanation_correct: The earth wire provides a low-resistance path for any leakage current to flow safely to the ground, protecting users from electric shocks. If any fault causes the metallic body of an appliance to become live, the earth wire carries the current to the ground.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The earth wire does not increase current or voltage, nor does it measure current. Its sole purpose is safety — it provides a path for leakage current to flow to the ground, preventing electric shock.

questions.question_text: A short circuit occurs when:

options.text: Live and neutral wires come in direct contact

questions.explanation_correct: A short circuit occurs when the live wire and neutral wire come in direct contact, creating a path of very low resistance. This causes a very large current to flow through the circuit, which can generate excessive heat and cause a fire. Fuses and MCBs are designed to protect against this.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A short circuit happens when live and neutral wires touch each other directly (or through a low-resistance path). An open circuit is when the circuit is broken. The fuse melts as a result of a short circuit, not the cause of it.

questions.question_text: Overloading in a domestic circuit can be caused by:

options.text: Connecting too many appliances on the same circuit

questions.explanation_correct: Overloading occurs when too many appliances are connected to the same circuit, drawing more current than the circuit can safely handle. This causes excessive heating of the wires, which can damage insulation and cause fires. Fuses and MCBs prevent this by breaking the circuit when current exceeds the safe limit.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Overloading is caused by connecting too many appliances, not by using fewer or switching them off. LED bulbs consume very little power and are unlikely to cause overloading. The total current drawn should not exceed the rated capacity of the circuit.

questions.question_text: The strength of the magnetic field of a solenoid can be increased by:

options.text: Increasing the number of turns per unit length

questions.explanation_correct: The magnetic field of a solenoid can be strengthened by increasing the number of turns per unit length, increasing the current flowing through the coil, or inserting a soft iron core. More turns per unit length means more concentrated field lines.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Increasing the number of turns per unit length increases the field strength. Decreasing the current or turns would weaken the field. A wooden core would not enhance the field like a soft iron core would.

questions.question_text: In Fleming's left-hand rule, the middle finger represents:
questions.explanation_correct: In Fleming's left-hand rule, the middle finger represents the direction of the current (I), the forefinger represents the direction of the magnetic field (B), and the thumb represents the direction of the force (F) or motion of the conductor.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In Fleming's left-hand rule: Thumb = Force/motion (Thrust), Forefinger = Field, Middle finger = Current. The middle finger represents current, not force or magnetic field.

questions.question_text: In Faraday's experiment, the galvanometer shows a deflection only when:

options.text: The magnet is stationary inside the coil
There is relative motion between the magnet and the coil
The coil is disconnected from the galvanometer

questions.explanation_correct: In Faraday's experiment, the galvanometer shows a deflection (indicating induced current) only when there is relative motion between the magnet and the coil. This motion causes a change in magnetic flux through the coil, which induces an EMF and current.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Current is induced only when the magnetic field through the coil is changing, which requires relative motion between the magnet and coil. A stationary magnet inside the coil produces no change in flux and hence no induced current.

questions.question_text: A compass needle is placed near a current-carrying conductor. The needle will:
questions.explanation_correct: A current-carrying conductor produces a magnetic field around it. This magnetic field interacts with the magnetic needle of the compass, causing it to deflect from its normal north-south orientation. This was first demonstrated by Oersted.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A current-carrying conductor creates a magnetic field that affects the compass needle, causing it to deflect. This was Oersted's discovery in 1820 — that electric current produces a magnetic effect.

questions.question_text: The function of the brushes in a DC motor is to:

options.text: Provide electrical contact with the rotating commutator

questions.explanation_correct: Carbon brushes in a DC motor maintain electrical contact with the rotating split ring commutator. They press against the commutator and allow current to flow from the external circuit to the rotating coil, enabling continuous rotation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Brushes do not create the magnetic field (that is the job of the magnets), reduce friction (they actually cause some friction), or generate current. Their role is to maintain electrical contact with the rotating commutator to supply current to the coil.

questions.question_text: The device used to prevent damage to appliances due to overloading or short circuit is:
questions.explanation_correct: A fuse or MCB (miniature circuit breaker) is used to protect appliances and wiring from damage due to overloading or short circuits. The fuse wire melts and breaks the circuit when excessive current flows. An MCB trips (opens) automatically.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ammeters and voltmeters are measuring instruments. A galvanometer detects small currents. Fuses and MCBs are safety devices that break the circuit when the current exceeds the safe limit.

questions.question_text: If the direction of current in a solenoid is reversed, the magnetic poles of the solenoid will:
questions.explanation_correct: When the direction of current in a solenoid is reversed, the north and south poles of the solenoid get interchanged. The end that was previously the north pole becomes the south pole and vice versa, because the direction of the magnetic field inside the solenoid reverses.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Reversing the current reverses the magnetic field direction, so the poles interchange. They do not disappear or remain the same. The strength remains the same (assuming current magnitude is unchanged).

questions.question_text: When a magnet is pushed into a coil, the galvanometer shows a deflection to the right. When the magnet is pulled out, the deflection will be:
questions.explanation_correct: When the magnet is pulled out of the coil, the change in magnetic flux is in the opposite direction compared to pushing it in. Therefore, the induced current reverses, and the galvanometer deflects to the left (opposite direction).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The direction of induced current depends on the direction of change of magnetic flux. Pulling the magnet out creates an opposite change in flux compared to pushing it in, so the galvanometer deflects in the opposite direction (to the left).

questions.question_text: The SI unit of magnetic field strength (magnetic flux density) is:
questions.explanation_correct: The SI unit of magnetic field strength (magnetic flux density) is the tesla (T), named after Nikola Tesla. 1 tesla is defined as the field intensity generating one newton of force per ampere of current per metre of conductor.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The SI unit of magnetic field strength is the tesla (T), not ampere, volt, or newton. Ampere is for current, volt for potential difference, and newton for force.

questions.question_text: Magnetic field lines form continuous closed loops.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is true. Magnetic field lines form continuous closed loops — they emerge from the north pole, travel through the external space to the south pole, and continue through the interior of the magnet from south to north. They have no beginning or end.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Magnetic field lines do form continuous closed loops. Unlike electric field lines (which start on positive charges and end on negative charges), magnetic field lines are always closed curves with no starting or ending point.

questions.question_text: A current-carrying conductor does not produce any magnetic field around it.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. A current-carrying conductor produces a magnetic field around it. This was first discovered by Oersted when he observed that a compass needle deflected near a current-carrying wire. The direction of the field is given by the right-hand thumb rule.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A current-carrying conductor does produce a magnetic field around it. This is the fundamental discovery of Oersted (1820). The magnetic field lines form concentric circles around the conductor.

questions.question_text: An electric motor works on the principle of electromagnetic induction.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. An electric motor works on the principle that a current-carrying conductor placed in a magnetic field experiences a force (motor effect/Fleming's left-hand rule). Electromagnetic induction is the principle behind electric generators, not motors.
questions.explanation_incorrect: An electric motor does not work on electromagnetic induction — that is the principle of a generator. A motor works on the motor effect: a current-carrying conductor in a magnetic field experiences a force (Fleming's left-hand rule).

questions.question_text: In a generator, slip rings produce alternating current (AC).
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is true. In an AC generator, slip rings (continuous rings) maintain contact with the brushes and allow the current to flow in alternating directions as the coil rotates. The output is alternating current. A DC generator uses split rings (commutator) instead.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Slip rings in a generator do produce AC. They maintain continuous contact and do not reverse the connections, so the naturally alternating current produced by the rotating coil is delivered as AC output.

questions.question_text: The earth wire is connected to the metallic body of an appliance.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is true. The earth wire is connected to the metallic body (casing) of electrical appliances. If due to any fault the live wire touches the metallic body, the current flows through the earth wire to the ground instead of passing through the user's body, preventing electric shock.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The earth wire is indeed connected to the metallic body of appliances as a safety measure. If the live wire touches the casing, the leakage current flows to the ground through the earth wire, protecting the user.

questions.question_text: Magnetic field lines never ___ each other.
questions.explanation_correct: Magnetic field lines never intersect (or cross) each other because at any point, the magnetic field has a unique direction. If two lines crossed, the compass needle would have to point in two directions at the same point, which is impossible.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'intersect'. Magnetic field lines cannot cross because the field has only one direction at any given point. Two crossing lines would imply two different directions at the same point.

questions.question_text: The ___ rule is used to find the direction of the magnetic field around a straight current-carrying conductor.
questions.explanation_correct: The right-hand thumb rule (Maxwell's corkscrew rule) is used for this purpose. If the right thumb points in the direction of current, the curled fingers indicate the direction of the magnetic field lines.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'right-hand thumb'. This rule states: if the thumb of the right hand points in the direction of current flow, the curled fingers give the direction of the circular magnetic field.

questions.question_text: An electric motor converts ___ energy into mechanical energy.
questions.explanation_correct: An electric motor converts electrical energy into mechanical (rotational) energy. It uses the force experienced by a current-carrying conductor in a magnetic field to produce rotation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'electrical'. An electric motor takes in electrical energy and converts it into mechanical energy (motion). A generator does the reverse — converting mechanical energy to electrical energy.

questions.question_text: An electric generator works on the principle of ___.
questions.explanation_correct: An electric generator works on the principle of electromagnetic induction, discovered by Faraday. When a coil is rotated in a magnetic field, the changing magnetic flux through the coil induces an EMF and current.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'electromagnetic induction'. The generator uses the principle that a changing magnetic field near a conductor induces a current. This was discovered by Michael Faraday.

questions.question_text: The colour of the earth wire in a domestic circuit is ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The earth wire in a domestic electric circuit is green (or green with yellow stripes). The live wire is brown (or red in old code) and the neutral wire is blue (or black in old code).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'green'. The earth wire is always green (sometimes with yellow stripes). It provides a safety path for leakage current to flow to the ground.

questions.question_text: In a DC motor, the split ring commutator reverses the ___ every half rotation.
questions.explanation_correct: The split ring commutator in a DC motor reverses the direction of current flowing through the coil every half rotation. This ensures that the torque on the coil always acts in the same direction, enabling continuous rotation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'current'. The commutator reverses the direction of current through the coil every half turn, so the force always pushes the coil in the same rotational direction.

questions.question_text: Fleming's ___ hand rule is used to find the direction of induced current.
questions.explanation_correct: Fleming's right-hand rule is used to find the direction of induced current in electromagnetic induction. The thumb represents motion, the forefinger represents the magnetic field, and the middle finger gives the direction of the induced current.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'right'. Fleming's right-hand rule is for generators/induction, while Fleming's left-hand rule is for motors/force on conductor.

questions.question_text: The magnetic field due to a current-carrying circular loop at its centre depends on:

options.text: The current and the radius of the loop

questions.explanation_correct: The magnetic field at the centre of a current-carrying circular loop depends on both the current flowing through it and the radius of the loop. Increasing the current increases the field, while increasing the radius decreases the field at the centre.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The field at the centre depends on both current and radius. More current means stronger field, while a larger radius means the field is spread over a larger area, making it weaker at the centre.

questions.question_text: Closely packed field lines represent:
questions.explanation_correct: When magnetic field lines are closely packed (dense), they represent a strong magnetic field. Widely spaced field lines indicate a weak field. The density of field lines at a point is proportional to the strength of the magnetic field at that point.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Closely packed (dense) field lines indicate a strong magnetic field, not a weak one. Where lines are spread out, the field is weaker. This is true for both magnetic and electric field lines.

questions.question_text: Which device is used in an electric bell?
questions.explanation_correct: An electric bell uses an electromagnet. When current flows, the electromagnet attracts the iron strip connected to the hammer, which strikes the bell. The circuit is then broken, the electromagnet loses magnetism, the strip returns, and the cycle repeats rapidly.
questions.explanation_incorrect: An electric bell uses an electromagnet, not a permanent magnet, generator, or galvanometer. The electromagnet can be repeatedly magnetised and demagnetised, which makes the hammer strike the bell repeatedly.

questions.question_text: The fuse wire is always connected in the live wire.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is true. The fuse is always connected in series with the live wire. This ensures that when excessive current flows and the fuse melts, the supply of current to the appliance is immediately cut off, making the appliance safe.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The fuse is indeed connected in the live wire (in series). If it were in the neutral wire, the appliance would remain at live potential even after the fuse melts, which would be dangerous.

questions.question_text: Which of the following does NOT increase the induced current in a coil?

options.text: Increasing the number of turns in the coil
Keeping the magnet stationary inside the coil

questions.explanation_correct: Keeping the magnet stationary inside the coil does not change the magnetic flux, so no current is induced. The induced current can be increased by: moving the magnet faster (faster change in flux), using a stronger magnet (more flux), or increasing the number of turns (more EMF per unit change in flux).
questions.explanation_incorrect: When the magnet is stationary, there is no change in magnetic flux through the coil, so no current is induced. All other options increase the rate of change of magnetic flux, thereby increasing the induced current.

questions.question_text: The scientist who first discovered that a current-carrying conductor produces a magnetic field was ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Hans Christian Oersted, a Danish physicist, discovered in 1820 that a current-carrying conductor produces a magnetic field around it. He observed that a compass needle placed near a wire carrying current showed deflection.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'Oersted'. Hans Christian Oersted discovered the magnetic effect of electric current in 1820 when he noticed a compass needle deflecting near a current-carrying wire.
